newsitem.title: USA: Clinton reinstates airline ticket tax.
newsitem.headline: Clinton reinstates airline ticket tax.

text.p: President Bill Clinton signed a bill reimposing the 10 percent airline ticket tax until Sept. 30, the White House said on Saturday.
Spokesman David Johnson said Clinton signed the bill on Friday night after it passed both houses of Congress during the week. His action was expected. The tax becomes effective in six days.
The ticket tax expired Dec. 31, 1996. Revenues from the tax go to the airport and airways trust fund which is used to pay for improvements at airports and in the air traffic control system.

Administration officials said the trust fund might run out of money next month unless the tax was reimposed. But some conservative House members opposed reinstating the tax unless it included an offsetting tax cut.
Several major airlines say the tax is unfair to them and have asked Congress to replace it with user fees.
